Fields.DialogueText: Greetings, Admiral Scheer!
Willkommen an Bord, Kapitän.
It's a pleasure to finally meet you. You've certainly got quite a reputation among the Belles!
Ist das so? I was not aware that I was much spoken of amongst the Walküren of the Fleet.
As it happens, you've attracted a fair amount of attention for... how should I phrase it? Running a tight ship?
It is common sense to run a tight ship, Kapitän. Why would that give me any sort of reputation?
Well, when you fought in the war between the Nationalists and Republicans in Spain...
Germany was committed to non-intervention in that conflict, and I sailed with the Non-Intervention patrol. However, I still needed a disciplined crew to ensure we were ready for any situation.

Fields.MenuText: I heard you bombarded the Republicans at Almería with 200 rounds, leveling 35 buildings. A little excessive, maybe?
The sailors who served with you said they hardly got any sleep during their entire tour.
The crew said you had them constantly servicing the torpedos every day, even though you never had to fire them.

Fields.DialogueText: The Republican air force bombed our cruiser Deutschland first - they killed 31 sailors and caused several large fires.
This is a warship, Kapitän, not a luxury cruise ship.
Although we were neutral, operational requirements demanded that were constantly... aware of the activities of the other fleets in the area.
The retaliation had to be swift and disproportionate. That was the only way to deter further attacks.
There is no problem torpedos cannot solve if properly applied, Kapitän.
I see. We're just getting to know each other, and that's all in the past now, so I suppose there's no need to debate over what should have been the right course of action.
Regular maintenance of all weapons systems is critical to ensure they perform as intended when the need arises.
Debate is inefficient for making timely decisions, Kapitän. If our current objective is to defeat the Morganas, we must analyze the enemy and move quickly to seize the initiative.
I'm starting to understand where this reputation comes from...
*BOOM*
Ah, the Nixen approach, Kapitän! We must observe their tactics and collect as much data as possible to devise the best strategy for their destruction.
You can do whatever you like, Admiral Scheer, but the most pressing concern at the moment is to return fire!
Ja, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Did you learn anything about the Morganas in that last battle, Admiral Scheer?
Ja, Kapitän. They are quite assertive!
That's putting it mildly. The consensus across the fleet is that these Morganas are mindlessly destroying anything in their path.
They are aggressive, Kapitän, but one should not assume it is because they are mindless.

Fields.MenuText: That's true, but we haven't been able to figure out any real logic to their attacks...
Yes, there must be some sort of larger strategy behind their actions...
I'm pretty sure they only want to sink anything that moves.

Fields.DialogueText: It demands further investigation, Kapitän. Once we can determine their objective and tactics, we can devise a way to break them.
We must probe them for weaknesses, Kapitän. Once we destroy what they value, they will submit to our demands.
If that is true, Kapitän, it simplifies the game immensely. We will merely sink as many of them as possible until they are no longer a threat.
Well, I'm sure those weren't the last Morganas we'll see on this sortie. You'll have plenty more opportunities to study them in combat and figure out what makes them tick.
What makes them tick? I hadn't considered that the Nixen might be powered by Uhrwerk...
It's a figure of speech, Admiral Scheer. I didn't mean it literally...
If they truly are machines, then we must find the weakest link, and--
*ALARM*
Hmm... these Morganas do seem to attack like clockwork. Maybe you're on to something, Admiral Scheer!
No problem can escape deduction and analysis, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Admiral Scheer is a noble name, of course - but is it okay if I just call you Scheer?
You make a good point, Kapitän - it is confusing to address me as an admiral when I do not hold that rank in reality.
Admiral Scheer was the Hero of the Skagerrakbattle, so there's still plenty of respect in calling you Scheer.
Thank you, Kapitän. I'll try to live up to the achievements of my namesake.

Fields.MenuText: Admiral Scheer's tactics at the Battle of Jutland have already made history.
His strong support for unrestricted submarine warfare during the Great War was merciless, but also practical.
They called him "The Man with the Iron Mask" because of his strict discipline... and severe expression.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! Imagine being outnumbered two to one in an engagement with nearly fifty battleships! The mere thought of the tactics required to win in that position... excites me!
Ja, Kapitän! Sinking the enemy's merchant ships without warning is a brilliant way to deny their fleet supplies and fuel. The mere thought of it... excites me!
Leading a fleet is not a beauty contest, Kapitän! His appearance is of no importance. However, the thought of Admiral Scheer's strict discipline does... excite me!
That's... a bit of a strange thing to get excited about... Nonetheless, he really was a great strategist.
It's true, Kapitän! He was also a technician, and quite a torpedo specialist! In fact, I wish he was around to solve all these torpedo problems the Kriegsmarine has had lately...
*BOOM*
Unfortunately, the Morganas aren't having any problems with their torpedoes...
Ja, Kapitän - but we will discover their weakness soon enough!
@BATTLE
What's that you've got there, Scheer?
It's a Notizbuch, Kapitän. More precisely, Notizbuch, Band 273.
I see. So what exactly are you taking notes on?
Investigating the Nixen is the main task, but we must also take inventory of our own capabilities. To start with, I'm examining the composition and operation of die Mannschaft.
That's very useful! Any major findings with our crew?
Die Mannschaft seems to be operating at a less than efficient level, Kapitän.
Less than efficient? I find that hard to believe! This is one of the most disciplined and hardworking crews I've ever served with.
Nein, Kapitän - they spend too much time idle. We could increase productivity by 20% if we cut back on time the crew spends sleeping and eating.

Fields.MenuText: Getting enough time to sleep and eat is essential for maintaining crew readiness and morale. We can't cut back on that!
Most of the crew is barely getting six hours of sleep a day. It would be dangerous to reduce it any further.
Meals are daily rituals that build bonds between the crew. The food isn't fancy, but who doesn't look forward to eating?

Fields.DialogueText: I fail to see how time spent not working can help the ship be more ready for combat.
A system down for maintenance 25% of the time out of every 24-hour period is unacceptable, Kapitän.
I don't understand why die Mannschaft must refuel so often. The ship is capable of sailing over 9,100 nautical miles without stopping.
The crew isn't just another piece of equipment on the ship, Scheer. People are different from machines.
Ist das so, Kapitän? I don't understand what you mean.
Ships are brilliant expressions of human engineering, and yes - we do need to maximize all the engineering and weapons systems on board to defeat the Morganas.
But the crew is composed of over 1,000 different sailors. They're all individual human beings with their own motivations, and we all have to work together as a team to operate this ship.
I see... so then I must inspect the 1,000 subsystems separately, and devise individual courses of action for optimizing the performance of each sailor?
Well... not exactly, but I think you're starting to understand the difference between human beings and--
*ALARM*
This talk is intriguing, Kapitän! Belles are both humans and machines, but this does not seem to be the case with die Mannschaft. Let us discuss more after destroying these Morganas!
@BATTLE
Great fighting in that last battle, Scheer!
Danke schön, Kapitän. I have also been thinking about our discussion on how die Mannschaft is different from the other systems on the ship.
In the last battle, I watched the crew operating the guns. It was clear they were performing the required physical functions of loading and firing the guns.
But I also watched as they trembled at the sight of the Nixen. They still bravely worked the guns, even as they tired over the long battle. They cheered together when they sank the enemy.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, the crew has human emotions and morale, Scheer. They're not just machines.
The individual sailors are human, but when the crew is working well together, they run like a finely made Swiss watch!

Fields.DialogueText: Swiss watch? I doubt die Mannschaft could work as accurately and precisely as a Swiss watch... but perhaps we can get there with enough training...

Fields.MenuText: Machines are much more reliable than humans! If only we had machines that could fire without the help of a crew!

Fields.DialogueText: I am starting to understand, Kapitän. Don't worry - I am taking notes and learning!
One can only dream that such technology will exist some day, Kapitän!
In any case, I must study the sailors in more detail. After all, if die Mannschaft is not performing optimally, we will not be able to turn our weapons against the enemy.
Well, if you want to get to know the sailors, you could start by saying hello.
I would imagine it would be difficult to "get to know" the sailors just by saying "hallo."
Well, yes... but after you say hello, you can start chatting about other things. You know, make some small talk to get the conversation going.
What is "small talk", Kapitän?
Small talk? Well... it's asking little questions to get the conversation started, making it easier to ask more important questions later. Like asking "The weather is nice today, isn't it?"
I see. Please let me make a note of this. I will try this "small talk" as a method to assist with data collection on the sailors.
*ALARM*
Do you think I can try this "small talk" with the Nixen, Kapitän? It would be helpful to collect more information on their motivations.
I'm pretty sure small talk is useless with the Morganas, but you can try. You'll probably get better intel looking through your binoculars to help adjust our gunfire.
Ja, Kapitän!
Ahoi, Nixen! Schönes Wetter heute, was?
*BOOM*
Ach! You're right, Kapitän - small talk is useless with the Nixen! Commence firing!
@BATTLE
I don't think your small talk strategy is working with the die Mannschaft, Kapitän.
What do you mean, Scheer?
I followed your advice to say hello to a sailor, then engage in small talk to extract as much information as possible. However, the strategy only resulted in an end to the conversation.
Hmm... what did you say, exactly?
I said "Hallo, Obermaat Baumann." Obermaat Baumann was very cordial, but afterwards was unable to respond to my small talk.
I'm afraid to even ask what your "small talk" was...
My small talk was a little question to get started, as you suggested. "Are you aware of the optimal cruising speed for the ship, balancing operational requirements against fuel consumption?"
I'm pretty sure not every sailor on the ship is capable of answering that question, Scheer.
Obermaat Baumann shouted, "Nein, Frau Schiffsdame!", but then just stood there shaking without continuing the conversation.

Fields.MenuText: Your question was a little complicated. I'm sure Obermaat Baumann was just confused.
You never defined the "operational requirements" of the mission. How can anyone answer that question?
I'd just like to point out that you missed the mark entirely on this "small talk" thing...

Fields.DialogueText: Confused? That is unacceptable, Kapitän! Die Mannschaft must be knowledgable of the ship's capabilities!
... That is a very observant point, Kapitän. Of course the operational requirements would influence the required speed... I feel ashamed that I even asked such an incomplete question!
It was a little question, as you suggested, Kapitän. Is die Mannschaft so poorly trained that they can't even answer such a simple question?!
Please relax, Scheer. There's no need to shout on the bridge.
I apologize, Kapitän. You know I rarely get this... excited. I am only strict with die Mannschaft because I care about their safety - and their ability to support the destruction of our enemies.
*GUNFIRE*
No need to apologize, Scheer. I know your heart is in the right place, and we're all doing our best.
Sometimes I worry that our best may not be good enough, Kapitän...
No time to worry about that right now, Scheer - we need to sink these Morganas!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
What are you taking notes on now, Scheer?
The main guns, Kapitän. I am making note of their maintenance condition and ammunition status as part of my overall readiness evaluation.
That's very helpful, Scheer. What have you found so far?
The condition of the guns is acceptable, although we must conduct minor maintenance at the next port call. The remaining number of rounds is sufficient given our projected rate of expenditure.

Fields.MenuText: Big guns can win any battle, so I'm happy to know we're in good shape.
What about the condition of the crew? The guns are useless without a crew to operate them.
What if we start using more rounds during battle than your projections anticipate?

Fields.DialogueText: Kanonen are only one tool in our arsenal, Kapitän. If there's one thing that gets me excited, though - it's Torpedos!
Excellent point, Kapitän! I will engage in more small talk with the Geschützmannschaften right after this.
The projections are based on historical data from all of our past sorties, Kapitän. They should be quite accurate. If they are not, then we must examine our calculations for errors.
Well, I'm sure the real Admiral Scheer would be proud to have these big guns mounted on such a fast hull.
This ship is quite a balance between firepower and speed, Kapitän. There aren't too many ships out there that can outrun us and outgun us!
*BOOM*
These Morganas are something else, though! We can't seem to outrun them or keep them sunk!
Then we will have to carry on sinking them, Kapitän! Don't worry - I've calculated that we have enough rounds in the magazine for several more grinding battles!
Good to have you on board, Scheer! Let's get those guns firing!
@BATTLE
You seem to be taking a lot of notes there, Scheer.
Ah! Hallo, Kapitän! Ahem... the weather is nice today, isn't it?
Ha! Glad you're starting to work on those conversational skills of yours, Scheer. Maybe one day they'll stop calling you "The Belle with the Iron Mask."
Hmm... perhaps I need to adopt a more pleasant demeanor. I feel die Mannschaft is still resistant to my small talk investigation, Kapitän.
You really need to stop thinking of small talk as an investigation...
The only way I can improve the performance of die Mannschaft is to understand the sailors as individuals. I wish they would realize that my investigations are only motivated by my desire to help.
Well, I know you're trying your best, Scheer. You'll figure things out eventually. Anyway, what are you taking so many notes on?
Aha! I see you are using small talk on me, Kapitän! You are quite the investigation expert yourself! If you really must know, I am taking notes on our Torpedos.

Fields.MenuText: First the guns and now the torpedoes - you're doing a thorough analysis of every weapon we've got, aren't you?
So what have you noticed about our torpedoes?
Torpedos are the only weapons we have that really... excite me!

Fields.DialogueText: Natürlich, Kapitän! Every weapon we have is important. I will examine our Flaks next. However, no other weapon excites me as much as the Torpedo!
Our Torpedos are beautiful, Kapitän! I find them extremely... exciting! What other weapon can silently destroy a merchant ship from a distance? The elegance of a Torpedo is unmatched!
Ja, Kapitän! I'm glad you share my enthusiasm for such a clever and deadly weapon!
Unfortunately, we've been encountering a problem with Torpedoblindgängern, Kapitän.
Duds? Any idea what the problem is?
That's what I'm looking into, Kapitän. I always get so excited when we launch a Torpedo out of our tubes! Imagine my disappointment when nearly all of them are Blindgänger!
You do seem to get very excited about torpedoes. I can imagine the duds leave you very frustrated!
The detonation mechanism might have a faulty design, although it could be the depth control. I wish my namesake was around to lend his expertise! I would certainly small talk him about this!
*ALARM*
We've got Morganas ahead! Why don't we put a few torpedoes in the water to collect a little more data?
Ja, Kapitän! You really know how to get a Walküre excited!
@BATTLE
Literal iron mask notwithstanding.
Scheer, I didn't think I would run into you down here.
Hallo, Kapitän! I came down to the Maschinenraum to collect more information, and ended up having a good conversation with the Maschinist.
Ah, nice to see the crew warming up to you!
Ja, Kapitän! I was small talking the Maschinist about the differences between Diesel and steam turbine engines. We discussed for over an hour until the end of the watch.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't sound like small talk, but it's good that you're improving your conversation skills!
How interesting! So what is the difference between Diesel and steam turbine power?
Over an hour talking about engines? That's the exact opposite definition of exciting.

Fields.DialogueText: In the course of our conversation, we also devised a way to increase fuel efficiency by 0.2 percent!
Kapitän, I know you are quite a technician yourself, but it would take several minutes to explain the differences in the detail required. I'm sure you're too busy for that at the moment.
It's always fascinating discussing technical details with someone who knows their field, Kapitän!
Well, it sounds like it was a productive conversation. The more comfortable everyone is communicating with each other, the better we'll fight as a team.
I agree, Kapitän! What business brought you down to the Maschinenraum?
Ah, just doing my normal round of inspections, Scheer. It's important to stay in touch with the crew and equipment, so I'm glad you're doing the same.
*ALARM*
That's probably the Morganas again. Let's show them how well our crew can fight!
Ja, Kapitän! I don't mind testing a few more Torpedos either!
@BATTLE
I don't understand, Kapitän. Some of the sailors finished eating over 30 minutes ago, but they are still seated at the table.
Well, most of the sailors have an hour set aside in their schedules to eat meals.
I have been observing the sailors, Kapitän, and it seems like most finish eating in under 15 minutes.
The hour isn't just for eating, Scheer. It's also for resting and chatting with other sailors. After a little break, the sailors go back to work with a lot more focus and energy.
I see, Kapitän. So sailors require a lot of maintenance time, but it allows them to be more productive when they return to service.

Fields.MenuText: Exactly! I'm glad you're starting to understand how people work.
You need to stop thinking of sailors as machinery. That won't help you understand how human beings work.
Do you have any suggestions for how to improve productivity here in the mess?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course the sailors are all individuals, Kapitän, but on a larger scale, die Mannschaft acts no differently than a machine.
There are as many crew dedicated to cooking the food as there are eating it, Kapitän. Surely we could simplify the process of meal preparation to free up sailors for other tasks.
It is unfortunate that machines are more durable and require less servicing, but we must do what is required to maximize the readiness of the Mannschaft.
I do have to say that the good food does boost morale, though. Have you had any of today's Labskaus?
Labskaus? I have never tried it, but I do have a vague memory of my namesake as a Kadett, eating this mash of salted beef, potatoes and pickles...
Hmm... it seems like you have some memories from Admiral Reinhard Scheer himself! Here, try some of this Labskaus then...

Mein Gott, Herr Kapitän! Tasting this Labskaus is bringing back a rush of warm Kadettenschulen memories from Admiral Scheer. It's making me feel a strange... happiness... for a place I've never known!
Ha! Now you're feeling what the sailors feel when they taste good food in the mess! They're not machines, but a great meal can increase their morale tenfold!
I see, Kapitän! This feeling is... amazing! I have so much more energy now!
*ALARM*
Sorry to cut the meal short, Scheer, but it seems like we have Morganas to deal with!
Don't worry, Kapitän! I'm ready to fight! We must destroy the Nixen - and protect the Labskaus!
That's what all the sailors are fighting for, Scheer! Battlestations, everyone! Those Morganas will never lay a finger on our Labskaus!
@BATTLE
The incident with the Labskaus was very informative, Kapitän.
You should have seen the look on your face when you tasted it! It was like you were transported to another world!
The Labskaus and the memories it brought back gave me this inexplicable feeling to fight harder.
We could never achieve such an effect with the equipment on the ship, but if the food has the same impact on the performance of our Mannschaft, the Smuts have a vital utilitarian purpose, Kapitän!
That's why every member of the crew has an important role to play, including the cooks, Scheer.
What about those two sailors over there? They seem to be discussing something in hushed tones while smoking cigarettes. Their behavior is not a standard activity. In fact, it looks suspicious.

Fields.MenuText: They're on a smoke break, Scheer. It's nothing important.
Suspicious? I suppose they could be plotting a mutiny, but I'm pretty sure they're just relaxing and having a smoke.
They're just on a short break, Scheer. You're acting a little paranoid.

Fields.DialogueText: Sailors shouldn't be wasting time on unimportant matters. We still have to fix our Blindgängerproblem, Kapitän! They will have time to smoke after they achieve reliable Torpedo detonation!
Plotting a mutiny? This is what happens when sailors are idle, Kapitän! Do you know those two? I'll write their names down - and small talk them later...
They are speaking in low voices and using the cigarette smoke to obscure the movements of their lips, Kapitän. Clearly they are making efforts to conceal the contents of their conversation.
They're just taking a short break to chat, and having a smoke to relax, Scheer. Most of the sailors do this a couple of times a day.
These smoke breaks occur several times a day? This is unacceptable, Kapitän! It cuts into productivity while giving ample opportunities for subterfuge!
It's good for crew morale, Scheer, just like the Labskaus.
Smoking is a waste of money, Kapitän. Some also suspect that it has a negative impact on one's health.
*BOOM*
We just took a direct hit on the bow! When the ship itself starts smoking, that's definitely not healthy! Return fire and sink those Morganas, Scheer!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Smoking is bad for your health? Now you're really being paranoid, Scheer! Everyone smokes, so it couldn't possibly be unhealthy.
Maybe, but if it helps their nerves I'm not going to take it away from them.
Fleet regulations say smoking's okay, Scheer. I may agree with you, but one war at a time.

Fields.DialogueText: What's that you've got there, Scheer?
It's a letter that I wrote for Frau Marianne Besserer. She's the daughter of the late Admiral Reinhard Scheer, and was the one who christened me.
Oh, that's great that you keep in touch with her! If you don't mind me asking, what sorts of things do you write about?
Typically, I update her with maintenance reports on the status of the engines and weapons systems. When secrecy is not concerned, I occasionally update her on combat operations.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure she's thrilled to hear anything related to the ship named after her father.
Oh... you might want to update her on how you and the crew are doing every once in a while, too...
That sounds... exciting. What does she usually write back about?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! She takes a keen interest in my regular efficiency reports, although she never seems to be completely satisfied...
I have never thought to mention those things before, Kapitän! She is always fascinated by my efficiency reports, but perhaps she will also be interested in trivial details regarding die Mannschaft.
She writes back to acknowledge receipt of my brief, followed by short feedback on my performance over the last reporting period. If I do well, she sometimes sends a tin of Scho-Ka-Kola.
You have an unusual relationship, but at least you seem to understand each other.
Ja, although I wish to break from my routine reporting and ask for her advice regarding our current deficiencies, Kapitän.
Deficiencies? Like what?
Her father was quite an expert on Torpedos. I would like to inquire if she also has any knowledge on the subject. We need help solving our Blindgängerproblem.
I see... but Frau Besserer is a civilian, so I'm not sure how much time she's spent studying torpedoes. It doesn't seem very ladylike either...
Are there no civilian lady Torpedo aficianados, Kapitän? I find that very hard to believe.
You haven't been on shore very much, have you? Life on land might surprise you.
I like to do research to avoid surprises, Kapitän. But to be honest, I don't know very much about life on land. That's why I also want to ask Frau Besserer about my memory of the Admiral's Labskaus.
Hmm... she would be the best person to ask about that, Scheer! It's also a bit more normal for ladies to correspond about recipes than it is about torpedo design.
These are modern times, Kapitän. Das Geschlecht should play no role on how excited one feels to see a long, glistening Torpedo slide underneath the surface!
*GUNFIRE*
I suppose you have a point there, Scheer. Let's get rid of these Morganas, and continue this discussion later.
Ja, Kapitän! All this talk makes me excited to get our Torpedos in the water!
@BATTLE
Taking more notes there, Scheer?
Ja, Kapitän. I'm taking inventory of all the basic equipment on the deck. It's a bit of work, but I have a few sailors here to help lay everything out for inspection.
Excellent. Inventory's a bit dull, but a necessity if you want to make sure we have everything we need to accomplish the mission.
Inventory is quite stimulating, Kapitän! It's always good to know the tools we have available to dominate our enemies!

Fields.MenuText: Well, it's nice to see you working as a team to get the job done!
All you've got there are a bunch of mooring lines. How can you dominate enemies with a pile of rope?
Wouldn't it be faster if you did all this yourself?

Fields.DialogueText: I have been listening to the sailors small talk each other while they work. They are discussing football teams and player changes. The tactics involved are quite fascinating!
One must always be ready to dominate the enemy with whatever tool is available, Kapitän - be it a Torpedo or a simple length of rope.
Nein, Kapitän. This task requires both manual labor and close attention to paperwork. It is most efficient to work as a team.
Huh... it's always interesting to hear your unique take on things, Scheer!
It has also been nice talking to die Mannschaft while we work. I have been small talking them about their hometowns to learn more about life on land.
Hey, that actually sounds like small talk for once!
Ja, Kapitän! If the Nixen ever gain the ability to come ashore, I must have the proper intelligence to transition to a land campaign.
I should have guessed there was an ulterior motive for the small talk! How likely is it for the Morganas to come on land, anyway?
The story of "The Little Mermaid" has already set a precedent for such an event, Kapitän. We need to plan for such contingencies!
*ALARM*
The Morganas are still at sea for now, thank goodness!
We can use our existing operational plan for this type of encounter, Kapitän. We can start the engagement with gunfire, then... Torpedos!
@BATTLE
After a thorough study of both the ship's capabilities and the Nixens' behavior in battle, I have devised a plan to ensure their destruction, Kapitän.
That's great, Scheer! We've been fighting the Morganas for a while now, but haven't figured out how to put a dent in their activity.
Exactly, Kapitän. The Nixen have superior numbers and an unknown base of operations. Trying to beat them through attrition is a losing strategy.
So what do you suggest?
We must find one of their smaller squadrons and harass them without destroying them. They will naturally call for help, attracting the larger Nixendickschiffe.

Fields.MenuText: I see! This will draw their capital ships out into open water, where we can engage them in a decisive battle!
What if their capital ships overpower us?
Are you sure you can take on the biggest ships in the Morgana fleet? You're only a heavy cruiser, after all...

Fields.DialogueText: Precisely, Kapitän! We must draw them out before crushing them with overwhelming firepower!
We will catch them by surprise, Kapitän, but we will still maintain an advantage in speed. If we fail to sink them quickly, we can always slip away.
I punch well above my weight, Kapitän! Do not underestimate my capabilities!
We always have trouble finding the Morganas' main fleet, but are endlessly attacked by their smaller squadrons. I hope this plan works.
It should work, Kapitän! In fact, I was inspired by Admiral Scheer's strategy of luring the numerically superior British ships out of their safe harbors during the Great War.
Ah, yes - by pressuring the coast with raids and U-boats, Admiral Scheer forced the Royal Navy to come out and fight, where they could quickly be surrounded.
Ja, Kapitän! It was a brilliant strategy, wasn't it?
I suppose... but remember that Germany still lost the war...
Because of the blunders of land generals, Kapitän! Admiral Scheer won the war at sea! Remember Jutland? Jutland was Scheer's masterpiece - his magnum opus! The thought of it makes me so... excited!
*BOOM*
Morganas again! They're always catching us off guard - I can't wait to turn the tables on them!
Don't worry, Kapitän. I have completed a full assessment of our ship and crew, as well as a study on the behavior of the Nixen. My proposed strategy cannot fail! We shall destroy them!
That sounds good to me, Scheer, but for now let's just return fire!
@BATTLE
We must find an optimally sized squadron of Morganas to begin the luring operation, Kapitän.
Right. If it's too small, then it won't be valuable enough to attract the attention of their capital ships...
Ja, and if it is too large, they will be able to defend themselves without calling for assistance.

Fields.MenuText: It'll be difficult to find the exact size squadron we need...
If only we were strong enough to take their capital ships head-on!
If only the Morganas had merchant ships - then we could use Admiral Scheer's unrestricted submarine warfare strategy!

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! Think of all the Torpedos we would get to fire! But unfortunately the Morganas seem to lack merchant ship convoys.
Ja, Kapitän, but it is essential for the plan. The plan will work if it is executed properly.
The strength of our plan is in catching them off-guard and swarming them like wasps, Kapitän. That way we negate both their firepower and numerical advantage!
You seem to have done all the research, and your plan makes the most sense given the situation.
It will take complex coordination for the required timing, Kapitän, but I have gotten to know the Mannschaft. I trust we are capable of performing the operation as planned.
*ALARM*
Morganas ahead, Scheer. Is this squadron big enough?
I don't think so, Kapitän. We'll just have to sink them as quickly as we can!
@BATTLE
Scheer! I wasn't expecting to see you in my quarters! Typically this area is off limits to everyone unless you've scheduled--
I inspected every square meter of the ship to prepare my plan to destroy the Nixen. But it occurred to me that there was one room left and one crew member I have failed to thoroughly small talk.
Scheer, we talk to each other all day long. We've had plenty of small talk.
It is nothing personal, Kapitän, but I just need to look around your quarters to finalize the information in your dossier.

Fields.MenuText: My dossier? So the rumors that you have a file for every member of the crew is true?
I really don't appreciate you poking around my quarters, Scheer. You've crossed the line this time!
Take as much time as you need, Scheer. I'm a very unexciting captain who has suitably unexciting quarters to match.

Fields.DialogueText: You suggested it yourself, Kapitän. You said I needed to understand all 1,000 crewmembers on a personal level. So I've been investigating about twenty sailors every day.
There's no such thing as privacy here, Kapitän. This entire ship belongs to the Kriegsmarine, and that includes the Kapitäns quarters.
I'll be the judge of that, Kapitän!
Scheer, this whole situation feels very confrontational. What's gotten into you?
If you have nothing to hide, then you have nothing to be afraid of, Kapitän. Please allow me a moment to look through the documents on your shelves and desk.
This is an incredible violation of privacy and protocol, Scheer!
Hmm... everything seems normal in these reports. Who are the people in these photographs? Your family, I presume?
What's the meaning of all this?
Okay, Kapitän, you seem to pose no threat. This was just a standard counterintelligence inspection. I was making sure you weren't passing any information to the Nixen.
Why in the world would I do that? We've risked our lives together countless times to fight those Morganas!
Ensuring the safety of everyone on board requires frequent inspections such as this, Kapitän. Apologies for bothering you with the small talk.
*BOOM*
That's another Morgana attack. I need to get to the bridge. Can you please get out of here so I can lock up my quarters?
Of course, Kapitän! I'll head to the deck to start directing fire. The destruction of the Nixen will be swift and without mercy!
You're one strange Belle, Scheer - but you come through when it counts!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Well, yes, of course!
Old friends, actually.
The pictures just came with the frames.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah - hello, Kapitän! That last battle was more difficult than expected, but you coordinated all of the ships brilliantly!
You're being awfully nice now. I'm still getting over you interrogating me in my own quarters.
Operational security is very important, Kapitän. I apologize if I appeared a bit harsh, but we must ensure everyone is trustworthy.
One never knows how close the crew is to mutiny, or if there are any spies on board.

Fields.MenuText: I can assure you that the crew is nowhere close to mutiny. In fact, morale is at the highest it's been in months!
Some of the crew members are pretty strange-looking, but we'd notice if one of them was a Morgana spy.
Has anyone investigated you yet?

Fields.DialogueText: The high morale is in part due to my efforts to improve the quality of food in the mess. I ordered the kitchen to serve Labskaus five days a week to help motivate die Mannschaft!
There are rumors the Nixen are shapeshifters, Kapitän. Plus, there is always the possibility of sympathizers amongst die Mannschaft.
Walküren and Nixen are fundamentally opposed, Kapitän. It's not possible for a Walküre to turn her support to the Nixen... or is it?
In any case, I'm glad your little investigation is over for now. If you ever want to inspect my quarters again, please just ask. It doesn't seem right for you to pick the lock without telling me.
Asking you beforehand would ruin an important element of surprise, Kapitän.
I'm clearly not going to win this argument! Speaking of the element of surprise, though, we still need to find a squadron of Morganas to use as bait to lure in a capital ship.
*GUNFIRE*
It sounds like the lookouts located a squadron of Nixen. Perhaps these are the ones we've been looking for?
I'm not sure, Scheer. Let's do a little investigating with our guns and torpedoes!
@BATTLE
It's taken a while to locate the perfect target, Kapitän, but I think this is it ahead of us.
What has you convinced this time, Scheer?
The squadron is moderately sized and not too strong. Reconnaissance also indicates a larger Nixe fleet nearby. Luring one of the Dickschiffe into open water where we can surround it will be easy.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we must strike decisively according to the plan!
Might as well give it a shot and see if it works out...
This plan sounds a little too perfect to end up working in reality.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! I admire your initiative and logic.
We must be decisive if we wish for the outcome to be as planned, Kapitän. Now is not the time to hesitate or second-guess!
The plan is sound, Kapitän. Now we must focus on the execution!
Okay, so what's the first step?
We make ourselves known to the squadron with a few warning shots. Then we close in and start with the harassing fire to push them into calling for reinforcements.
And when the help arrives, we immediately surround it with all of our smaller and faster ships?
Ja, Kapitän. Once they are surrounded, their only path of escape will be straight down to the bottom of the ocean.
Okay, here we go then! Fire a warning shot in front of that squadron of Morganas so they know we're serious.
Of course, Kapitän! This plan makes me so excited!
@BATTLE
It's working, Kapitän! Our warning shots have attracted the attention of the Nixengeschwader.
Yes, they're moving towards us to engage. It's all happening according to plan.
Ah, it always brings me great joy to see the enemy falling into my trap, Kapitän! It is like they are actors following my script to the letter!

Fields.MenuText: Now all we need to do is pressure them with enough harassing fire so they'll call for reinforcements.
Are you sure we've got enough firepower to take on the Morgana capital ships?
I'm sure any script you write ends up with half of the cast blown to bits!

Fields.DialogueText: We must exercise restraint, Kapitän, and suppress our natural desire to immediately destroy them.
Once we draw them out and surround them, we will have the advantage in both position and firepower, Kapitän!
My critics say I specialize in writing tragedies, but they're all on the losing side! Haha - do you understand my joke, Kapitän?
I'm still a bit worried about being outgunned if the Morganas send in some bigger ships, Scheer.
Have you seen the size of my guns, Kapitän? Everyone always talks about how big my Torpedos are too...
They're certainly intimidating, but they do call you a "pocket battleship."
I don't like that nickname, Kapitän. The British came up with it, and we were not on very friendly terms until quite recently.
The point is, we have firepower, but I'm not sure we have the size to take very many hits. We'll have to use our speed to our advantage.
Ja, Kapitän. I was designed to chase down merchant ships, but still outgun any escorts that could keep up with me. Very few Belles have my combination of speed and power.
I suppose I am like a noble Weimaraner in that respect - both strong and swift!
Well, you are a pocket battleship, so more like a tenacious dachshund than a Weimaraner...
I really don't like that nickname, Kapitän...
*BOOM*
The Morganas have moved in to engage. Let's get barking, Scheer!
I don't appreciate the direction your small talk has taken, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
So we just need to continue shelling them until they call for reinforcements?
Ja, Kapitän. The deception involves firing without destroying them too quickly.
Right, and we can't make it too obvious that we're trying to miss. It might make them suspicious and prevent them from calling for help.
We must make them fear without placing them in real danger.

Fields.MenuText: Just like a roller coaster ride, Scheer. We need to scare them without killing them.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah yes, just like a ride on an Achterbahn, Kapitän - although we will eventually destroy them all once the reinforcements arrive!

Fields.MenuText: It must be difficult for the gun crews to intentionally miss when we always train them to hit the target...
We could just shoot a bunch of torpedoes at them - they're mostly duds anyway.

Fields.DialogueText: It's only a matter of adding or subtracting a few degrees from the firing solution, Kapitän.
This is my most vexing problem, Kapitän! Solving the Blindgänger issue will be my main priority after this sortie.
We'll still have to sink a few of their ships now to avoid being overrun ourselves.
Ja, Kapitän, but we must go easy on them.
It's rare to hear you advocating for going easy on the enemy.
It is all part of the plan, Kapitän. However, I am finding it difficult to hold back my desire to launch more Torpedos...
All in good time, Scheer. I think we can sink a few of these Morganas if you really need to blow off some steam, though!
Vielen Dank, Kapitän! Torpedowerfer laden und klar zum Feuern machen!
@BATTLE
It's working, Kapitän! The Nixen are sending elements of their main fleet to assist!
Excellent! We're in a perfect position to catch them by surprise.
The thought of torpedoing a fat Nixendickschiff... excites me greatly, Kapitän!

Fields.MenuText: We've finally drawn out their big ships, and can do some major damage to their fleet!
Don't get too fixated on the torpedoes, Scheer. We have guns too!
We haven't hit anything yet, so don't count your torpedoes before they're launched.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! All wars are simply battles of attrition targeting resources. It will be a huge blow to the Nixen if we sink a Dickschiff!
The guns are powerful and can pound the enemy into dust, but they lack the elegance des Torpedos, Kapitän.
We must count our Torpedos both before and after launching, Kapitän. That is standard procedure!
The Morgana reinforcements are getting into gun range, Scheer. We'll have to settle for firing a few salvos before we get to the torpedoes...
Of course - there is a certain order to things, Kapitän! One must warm up the enemy with a few rounds of shelling before trying to slip a Torpedo under their hull!
I'd prefer to take care of them at artillery range. Shelling is always reliable. You've still been firing a lot of dud torpedoes over the last few engagements...
This is a very embarassing problem for me, Kapitän! I wish you would not speak so openly about it in front of die Mannschaft!
There's no privacy on this ship, Scheer - you said it yourself. In fact, it would be irresponsible of me not to report your torpedo problems to HQ. Perhaps you're in league with the Morganas?
Why would you accuse me of such a thing, Kapitän? Please don't...
Just a little joke, Scheer! It's part of my counterintelligence efforts. You're the last person on this ship who would side with the Morganas!
I don't quite understand your humor, Kapitän. Treason is punishable by death.
Hmm... you're really not the joking type, are you?
I suppose not, Kapitän - especially when Torpedos are involved. Now then, let's sink these Nixen!
@BATTLE
We've been outmaneuvered by their reinforcements, Kapitän! This wasn't part of the plan!
They're closing in fast! If we don't act quickly, they'll cross our T!
We still have our speed advantage, Kapitän. It's not too late to regain the initiative.

Fields.MenuText: We still have our first squadron of Morganas to deal with too. We should finish them off so we don't get surrounded.
Let's head straight for those reinforcements and engage!
What would Reinhard Scheer do?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän. We need to sink this Geschwader to free up room to maneuver.
We have a strong fleet, Kapitän, but we're not strong enough to overpower them directly.
Good question, Kapitän... he would clearly devise a plan that exploits our strengths while exposing their weaknesses.
Whatever we do, we need to decide quickly...
The final decision is yours, Kapitän, but we should fight through that first squadron and sink them to give us some space.
Good point, Scheer. We don't need the bait anymore, so we can sink them and go after the big fish!
Ja, Kapitän! I'm happy to make room by sinking a few Nixen. Die Schonzeit ist vorbei!
@BATTLE
Sinking that Nixengeschwader gave us a little room to maneuver, Kapitän.
The battle isn't over yet. Their main fleet is still positioned to cross our T. What can we do?
Hmm... remember Jutland, Kapitän?
Jutland? You mean the peninsula made up of Denmark and Germany?
Jutland....the English call it that. I mean the Skagerrakschlacht, natürlich! It was Reinhard Scheer's greatest victory in the largest engagement of battleships the world had ever seen!
He conducted three Gefechtskehrtwenden to prevent the enemy from crossing his T, then won the engagment in a ferocious night battle!

Fields.MenuText: That's exactly what we'll do - all of our ships can make a simultaneous 180° turn to avoid the T-crossing!
What in the world is a Gefechtskehrtwende?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! Who would have thought that Admiral Scheer's brilliant tactics could save us even now?
It is a simultaneous 180 degree turn by every ship in our formation, Kapitän. Oh, there's nothing more exciting than a well-executed Gefechtskehrtwende!

Fields.MenuText: There's no way we could replicate the precision of his maneuvers, though...

Fields.DialogueText: Die Mannschaft is well-trained and disciplined, Kapitän! I verified this during my small talk with them. They are up to the task!
Okay, then - let's take a hard 180° turn and outmaneuver these Morganas!
Ja, Kapitän, but we have more Nixen approaching from the opposite side!
We'll just have to fight our way through them, Scheer. Get your torpedoes ready!
My Torpedos are always ready to launch, Kapitän! All this combat is so... exciting!
@BATTLE
That last maneuver put us out of danger for a moment, but we're about to get our T crossed again!
We'll need that hard 180 degree turn, Scheer!
Jawohl, Kapitän! Our ships are still more maneuverable than the Nixen, so we must maintain an advantageous position!
It's times like this where I'm thankful we've got such a good crew - both at the helm and in the control tower.
Ja, Kapitän! I have small talked the whole crew, and have compiled over 1,000 dossiers on the sailors. I trust their skill and judgement in battle entirely.
Entirely? It must have been a very thorough investigation then! You were in my captain's quarters, so I suppose you've been in every sailor's bunk as well.
Ja, Kapitän. The bunk inspections were an item on the inspection checklist - just one out of many.

Fields.MenuText: One out of many? What else was on this checklist?
I'm glad you've gotten to know and trust the crew a bit more. It's important if we want to work together as a team.
Enough small talk, Scheer! We're in the middle of a battle!

Fields.DialogueText: The inspections were very thorough, Kapitän, but I am not free to divulge the full details of the investigations. Let's just say I was satisfied by the results.
Ja, Kapitän. I am confident that there are no spies or conspirators on die Mannschaft... at least as far as this inspection is concerned.
You were the one who started the conversation, Kapitän!
Anyway, we've got more Morganas headed our way. We're in danger of getting our T crossed again.
Another 180 degree turn, Kapitän, just like Admiral Scheer did at Jutland?
Yes, and don't be afraid to do it again if we run into any more trouble!
Ja, Kapitän! But tell me - when can I launch the Torpedos?
You've been waiting for my command on the torpedoes? I thought you would just start launching them once we were in range...
All this small talk has been distracting me from my other duties, Kapitän! Prepare the Torpedos at once!
@BATTLE
We've finally got those Nixen right where we want them, Kapitän! I knew everything would fall into place as long as we followed the plan!
Those maneuvers from Jutland worked brilliantly, Scheer! Launch all the torpedoes you want - we're going to sink every Morgana in sight!
*GUNFIRE*
@BATTLE
We did it, Kapitän! With a logical plan, and a disciplined and efficient Mannschaft, we can destroy any fleet that stands in our way!

Fields.MenuText: I'm beginning to understand the dedication behind your stern exterior. I'm glad you're a part of my crew.
When I hear you talk so seriously like that, I get so... excited!

Fields.DialogueText: I'm proud to serve with you too, Kapitän. We only expect the best from our Mannschaft - it's the only way we can accomplish our mission and bring everyone home safely.
Oh, Kapitän! On quiet nights at sea, I often wish I had a partner to small talk about Torpedos until the sunrise...
There's no Belle quite like you, Scheer.
I know some think I can be a bit strict, but it's not without reason. I'm glad we're getting to know each other a little bit more, Kapitän.
I appreciate your efforts to meet the crew halfway on things as well. Maybe they haven't all warmed up to you yet, but at least they're starting to understand your way of thinking.
Ja, Kapitän. Hmm... I'm feeling quite hungry after that last battle...
Want to head down to the mess? I heard Labskaus is on the menu today.
Oh, that sounds exciting, Kapitän! We can also small talk the sailors about the engines and Torpedos!
That sounds like a fantastic plan, Scheer. Let's go!
